content.text: WDC DD Western Digital Swings to 1Q Profit After AI Demand Stokes Sales

WDC hasn‚Äôt gotten any respect since Milligan bought Sandisk. Why? Becos HDD is a cash generative business and Flash eats up a lot of that cashflow. That‚Äôs why WDC trades as if the Flash business is worthless.

In a spin-off, the parentco‚Äôs stock usually drops by the value of the spinco stock. E.g. in a 1-for-1 spin, ParentCo stock would go from $65 to $55 if the spinco stock trades at $10 on ex-date‚Ä¶

But that‚Äôs not always the case. Once in a while, the parentco stock doesn‚Äôt drop at all, and might even rise. It‚Äôs rare. Why? This happens when the spinco is a huge profit or cashflow drag on the parentco. See the LAAC/LAC spin-off - the parentco surged after they spun off the valuable but troublesome spinco. And this lifted the concerns on the parentco so the stock jumped.

If I‚Äôm right that WDC gets no respect becos of Sandisk, then I won‚Äôt be surprised if WDC is flat or up after they spin off the Flash biz (which is dragging the stock down lately)
Recent insider selling doesn't help!

The continuing problem with WDC is respect.  It gets none from the market.  WDC (as a single entity) may earn more than STX, and about the same as MU (on an EPS basis).  Yet, those peers are given multiples of 12 to 15, and WDC struggles to get afforded a 10 (closer to 9).

To refresh everyone‚Äôs memory‚Ä¶.

Sandisk was acquired by WDC at $15.6B EV back in 2016 when LTM revenues were $5.5B (vs $7.5B in 2024)

Kioxia‚Äôs pulled IPO valued it at a disappointing $5.5B (equity value). With $10B in net debt, the implied EV was $15.5B. Kioxia has 30% more revenues than Sandisk but at lower margins and a significantly higher tax rate (30-35% vs mid-teens for Sandisk).

My guess is SNDK could fetch $12-15B in EV. But your guess is as good as mine.

We don‚Äôt know how much net debt will go to Sandisk. If it‚Äôs $2B, then its market cap could be $10-13B or $29-38 per WDC share‚Ä¶

Lots of people were worried about a nasty guidance becos of soft NAND pricing in Q4. Yes - we all saw the reports from Trendforce and DRAMexchange‚Ä¶

Anyways, this earnings announcement was the last risk hurdle before the spin-off. Investors who were worried had been waiting on the sidelines. Now that this hurdle is gone, investors who want to play the spin off will rush in.

After all, no other price sensitive event is on the calendar, except maybe the Analyst Day.

Since everyone knows the post-spin WDC HDD is likely to trade at a similar valuation to STX (so the SNDK spin-off stub is basically all upside), the stock is going to start pricing in the expected trading price of SNDK in the next few weeks‚Ä¶

Here is my take as an R&D engineer and hobby investor. WD has been a great company but waiting for the data revolution provided by the current big data approach to AI that is forever hungry for more data, and that enables apps and business models that are data-centric which produce and consume even more data. But just like the CD ROM that had its day, SSD now has a lower cost of ownership than HDD when you consider (a) its tiny power use and even tinier resting parasitic consumption and (b) its much smaller size. And that is forgetting that it is the tortoise and the hare comparison for speed needed by AI and any cloud app. One more generation of shrink and the cost of SSD per bit will be the same. So, HDD will be retired. Given that, WD only has its NAND side. This would be the real reason for splitting the company i.e. a clear view through the crystal ball. Same happened to vacuum tube monitors/TVs around 2008. Mechanical stuff will always be replaced by solid state if that is possible. It is happening now accelerated by AI. And that is why, after a lot of thinking this thru, I have stopped investing in WD as it really is a value trap that will then devalue after perhaps a short term pop. But the reason it has been going down is that the institutions see clearly that HDD will be retired soon and it is going to be hard to support WD's value if you write that side of the business off. But if you split it then writing off is an easier exercise.
Someone cares.  WD is up $0.88 in a massive down day.
The company sent out an email to its customers September 27 telling them about the website change.  The stock has been straight down since so no one cares...

MU slid and back-filled due to macro market conditions combined with additional gov talk about restricting sales to China that actually were already known and factored into future earnings. Hence WD also slid. I believe that WD is ahead of the earnings curve compared to MU right now and note that they overlap only on SSD. MU has HBM and DRAM whereas WD has HDD. WD has no tech that the US will ban to be exported to China so that is safe. Also, HDD requirements grow with long term data storage whereas SSD / DRAM / HBM grows with AI compute growth as they work as a team. So, I am going to say that WD is a safe more undervalued stock for now, but MU will overtake that after its next earnings not forgetting that big league investors still treat MU as cyclical DRAM earnings with HBM being only 10% of their revenue right now. So, my strategy for the next couple of months will be to get in and out of WD depending on macro conditions, then switch to MU before their next earnings. This is not being fickle btw, but realistic and strategic as my only goal is capital growth.

Based on MU's results I thought we would be heading up from here. We initially did but now we are backsliding. I'm guessing we are down with the rest of tech, including Micron. Sure hope we get a good Q3 in a few weeks time so we can get this thing back into the 70's.

Has to be the most undervalued value AI stock in history. Massively profitable and massive growth to come. Huge patent porfolio, both HDD and flash, and now eSSD specifically adapted to enterprise market. Forward guaranteed PE of about 7 because the order book is full for over a year. No earnings surprises to come except higher margins and more sales. No massive build out of capital rich manufacturing capacity as they already did that. And most stocks are on 20 to 40 forward PE if a risk plan pans out. So, complete technical and execution safety, no risk, guaranteed earnings and low PE, and massive AI growth as data storage requirements go exponential. And why would they even think to split the business when flash+HDD is a required combo for performance versus capacity? Only -ve is sentiment in a pre-AI era of cyclical PC markets which this is not. Seagate Technology (STX) is collaborating with its cloud partners to secure qualifications for its products in the cloud segment, Chief Financial Officer Gianluca Romano said at a technology conference Wednesday.The process is taking longer than expected due to the rigorous demands placed on the products, especially in core environments. But, the company has the ball rolling and is making good progress every week, Romano said, according to a Capital IQ transcript.The qualification process for the cloud segment may extend into the next quarter, but the company has made significant advancements in the on-premise data center, a crucial market segment where artificial intelligence-driven demand is expected to increase the consumption in the coming quarters.The company is confident in its heat-assisted magnetic recording, or HAMR, product despite delays and has begun working with multiple cloud customers in the US and China, expecting the full qualification process in around three quarters, with a ramp-up in volume expected by mid-2025, the executive said.HAMR's impact on profitability will remain limited until mid-2025

Separation - make of this transcript what you want.  It's not mine - so don't blame me for the gibberish.  But you can get the gist of it"We think these are better separate assets, especially around that they're executing extremely long. And so I think we started down our process. We announced it October 30 of last year. It's on a very big base inside the company with Super companies got 50,000-plus it‚Äôs -- it's 2 big franchises, we mean gibbon our path and we expect to getting to the plants month early October and we've got all of our IT systems separated. We've got our self-organized and where we can start operating 2 separate companies and make sure we can process orders, make sure we collect on in a road on an attributable to 2 separate businesses. It's called the soft spin in the parlance of people that do spins all the time. And we'll execute in that mode for the next quarter through the December quarter. And then when we get through that, we get conviction, we can close the books on 2 independent public companies. We'll do that most likely through the December quarter and then we'll go through the separation process. So a very long process."It's already been a long process (really 3+ years) and still going longer.

The AI story is data, Data, DATA. Algorithms and compute architectures come and go and develop and get optimized. Data is the driving force and is never discarded i.e. will always grow. And the more compute installed the more data is created and consumed. Compute total addressable markets work on rate of data which may one day reach an upper limit and may already be slowing. Storage is cumulative sum of data and there is no upper limit and with more compute comes more data and more apps bring more people's data online so data increase is accelerating. I believe your numbers, and they may be conservative. Margins will be pressured upwards as demand accelerates as well well as cost advantages with increased sales. And of course the more data that is maintained then the more drives get replaced within a lifecycle as a secondary market that is forever.Data storage is the real AI story and is future proof and safe.

You are right!  And HDD gross margin and revenue was outstanding

2) The HDD division is outperforming Seagate massively. WDC HDD was 16% and 21% larger than STX‚Äôs HDD sales and gross profits respectively. WDC HDD grew 55% y/y vs STX HDD growth of 25% y/y. Note that WDC HDD will trade on its own after the spin-off so investors can own it (instead of STX) 

3) $5.6B in net debt will likely drop significantly as the convertible falls off. Here‚Äôs why.

WDC issued $1.6B in convertible debt last year to retire an older convert. 

This new convert has a conversion price of $52/share but WDC hedged it with a call spread at $70/share. In plain English, the accounting rules require WDC to increase the fully diluted share count by 23M (1600/70) whenever the stock price rises above the $70 hedge so as to assume full conversion from debt into shares BUT it doesn‚Äôt get to assume the $1.6B debt will go away upon conversion. So they took the hit for share dilution but not the benefit of $5.6B in net debt falling to $4B (if/when the debt is converted, which will happen as long as the stock is above $52/share)

Ok, guys. I Just went through the numbers, and the earnings are actually a lot better than it looks. I won‚Äôt be surprised if the stock closes in the green tomorrow :) Here‚Äôs what the after-hours sellers are missing‚Ä¶.

TL;DR EPS guidance was solid, WDC HDD is hitting it out of the park and net debt is likely to go down significantly.

1) EPS guidance is actually a lot better than it looks

Guide for EPS $1.70 midpoint (vs $1.73 consensus) looks like a miss but it includes three non-operating items that are not in consensus numbers:

a) $15-25M in separation costs

b) 15-17% tax rate vs 8% expected

c) Higher share count 360M vs 349M

These non-operating costs add up to a $0.25 hit to the EPS guide i.e. the apples-to-apples guide is $0.22 above consensus. And likely conservative given the past pattern of crushing their own guidance‚Ä¶
